Indicted by the [[International Criminal Court|ICC]] for [[war crime]]s and [[crime against humanity|crimes against humanity]] }} {{See also|Effacer le Tableau}} '''Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo''' (born 4 November 1962){{cite web|publisher=International Criminal Court|date=23 May 2008|url=http://www.legal-tools.org/en/doc/fb0728/|title=Situation In The Central African Republic In The Case Of The Prosecutor V. Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo — Under Seal Urgent Warrant Of Arrest For Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo|accessdate=3 June 2017|id=ICC-01/05-01/08-1-tENG-Corr}} is a politician in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. He was one of four [[Vice Presidents of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|vice-presidents]] in the transitional government of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] from 17 July 2003 to December 2006. Bemba also leads the [[Movement for the Liberation of the Congo]] (MLC), a [[Rebellion|rebel]] group turned [[political party]]. He received the second-highest number of votes in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2006|2006 presidential election]]. In January 2007 he was elected to the [[Senate of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Senate]]. He was arrested near [[Brussels]] on 24 May 2008 on an arrest warrant issued by the [[International Criminal Court]].International Criminal Court (24 May 2008). ''[http://www.icc-cpi.int/press/pressreleases/370.html Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo arrested for crimes allegedly committed in the Central African Republic] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527070253/http://www.icc-cpi.int/press/pressreleases/370.html |date=27 May 2008 }}''. Retrieved on 25 May 2008. He was originally charged with three counts of [[crime against humanity|crimes against humanity]] and five counts of [[war crime]]s committed by fighters under his command, in October 2010 the ICC reduced the charges to two counts of crimes against humanity and three counts of war crimes.Staff (19 October 2010) [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11573604 "ICC to proceed with Bemba war crimes trial"] ''BBC News'' On 21 March 2016, he was convicted on these charges. On 21 June 2016, he was imprisoned on an 18-year sentence in landmark conviction at the International Criminal Court (ICC) for war crimes and sexual violence. On 28 September 2016, he appealed his conviction alleging a mistrial and citing errors in the trial chamber's analysis of his superior responsibility.{{cite web|url=https://www.ijmonitor.org/2016/10/bemba-lays-out-grounds-for-appeal-against-icc-conviction/|title=Bemba Lays Out Grounds for Appeal Against ICC Conviction|website=www.ijmonitor.org|accessdate=8 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cpi.int/Pages/record.aspx?docNo=ICC-01/05-01/08-3434-Red|title=Public Redacted Version of Appellant’s document in support of the appeal|publisher=|accessdate=8 June 2018}} His 2016 war crimes convictions were overturned following an appeal on 8 June 2018;{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/06/08/618273154/former-congolese-vice-president-cleared-of-war-crimes-conviction-on-appeal|title=Former Congolese Vice President Cleared Of War Crimes Conviction On Appeal|publisher=National Public Radio {NPR)|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en}} however, in September, he lost his appeal against his conviction for witness tampering.{{Cite news|title=ICC sentences DRC's Jean-Pierre Bemba over witness tampering |date=17 September 2018 |newspaper=Al Jazeera |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/09/icc-sentences-drc-jean-pierre-bemba-witness-tampering-180917131831205.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180917170953/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/09/icc-sentences-drc-jean-pierre-bemba-witness-tampering-180917131831205.html |archive-date=17 September 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy}} He was released in June 2018, and returned to the DRC, where he was running for [[President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2018|2018 election]], where he was considered to be the strongest opposition candidate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2018/08/08/joseph-kabila-says-he-will-not-run-again-in-congo|title=Joseph Kabila says he will not run again in Congo|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}} However, he could be barred from the election because, under the laws of the DRC, individuals found guilty of corruption are prohibited from running for president. He has stated that he is willing to back another opposition candidate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2018/09/dr-congo-former-warlord-says-he-would-back-opposition-candidate/|title=DR Congo former warlords says he would back opposition candidate|date=17 September 2018|publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM]] through [[Agence France-Presse]]|access-date=18 September 2018|language=en}} ==Background== Bemba was born in Bokada, [[Nord-Ubangi]]. His father, [[Jeannot Bemba Saolona]], was a businessman who was successful under [[Zaire|Zairian]] President [[Mobutu Sese Seko]], and one of his sisters is married to Mobutu's son [[Nzanga Mobutu|Nzanga]], who was also a candidate in the 2006 presidential election.Kurt Wagner, [http://www.wsws.org/articles/2006/aug2006/cong-a25.shtml "Run-off ballot in the Congo"], World Socialist Web Site, 25 August 2006. ==MLC in Équateur== The MLC movement started in the [[Orientale Province]] of the DRC in 1998 at the beginning of the [[Second Congo War]]. Little by little, the movement moved into the [[Équateur (former province)|Équateur]] province, and established a permanent base in [[Gbadolite]].http://ajpba.org/pdf/20110629.pdf This region had been decimated by war and the population was living in great poverty. Équateur was under an embargo: healthcare programs, education, and any kind of social assistance had been abandoned. The population was under constant threat of bombing by government forces, and had stopped producing goods or food. When the MLC troops arrived in Gbadolite, they secured the area and protected the population. Health centres and hospitals re-opened with the MLC securing safe passage for medicine and other supplies. The MLC worked with NGOs and the UN to reopen schools, restart agriculture, economic activity and exportations of goods. The population was able to sell coffee, corn and soya and build businesses.https://www.icc-cpi.int/Transcripts/CR2016_04024.PDFhttp://www.legal-tools.org/doc/297cf6/pdf/ ==Involvement in the Central African Republic== In 2002, President [[Ange-Félix Patassé]] of the [[Central African Republic]] invited the MLC to come to his country and put down a coup attempt. Human rights activists accused MLC fighters of committing atrocities against civilians in the course of this conflict. ==Vice President== In 2003 Bemba became vice-president under a peace deal. ==2006 Presidential election== Bemba was one of 33 candidates who ran in the Congolese [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2006|presidential election]] on 30 July 2006. His main campaign slogan — "One Hundred Percent Congolese" — was widely perceived as an attack on frontrunner President [[Joseph Kabila]].[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/15/AR2006081500718.html "Vote Count Continues in Congo Election"], ''[[Washington Post]]'', 15 August 2006. Bemba received substantial support in the western, [[Lingala language|Lingala]]-speaking portion of the country, including the capital, [[Kinshasa]].[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55218&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes&SelectCountry=DRC "Frontrunners need alliances for 2nd round of presidential polls"], IRIN, 22 August 2006. Following the vote there was significant tension as to whether Kabila would win a majority of the vote, avoiding a runoff against Bemba, who was perceived as Kabila's main opponent.[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55173&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes "Tension ahead of election results"], IRIN, 18 August 2006. However, results announced on 20 August gave Kabila 44% of the vote and Bemba 20%, On 21 August 2006, while accompanied by 14 ambassadors of CIAT members (International Committee in charge of the Transition), including ambassadors from the United States of America, Britain, France (Bernard Prévost) and Belgium ({{ILL|Johan Swinnen|de|Johan Swinnen (Diplomat)}}), and from MONUC, US diplomat [[William L. Swing]], Bemba survived an assassination attempt by the Presidential Guard bombing his residence in Gombe. The ambassadors were forced to seek refuge in a cellar.[[:fr:Tensions Kabila-Bemba en 2006 et 2007]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.la-croix.com/Archives/2006-08-23/Les-partisans-de-Kabila-et-Bemba-s-affrontent-dans-Kinshasa-_NP_-2006-08-23-270210|title=Les partisans de Kabila et Bemba s'affrontent dans Kinshasa|date=23 August 2006|publisher=|accessdate=8 June 2018|via=www.la-croix.com}} Kabila and Bemba faced each other in a second round, held on 29 October. The electoral commission announced the official results on 15 November, naming Kabila the winner with 58.05% of the vote; Bemba's supporters have alleged fraud.BBC News (2006-11-15). "Kabila named DR Congo poll winner". BBC News, 15 November 2006. Retrieved from http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6151598.stm. On 27 November 2006, the Supreme Court of the DRC rejected the fraud charges brought by Bemba, and confirmed Kabila as the new elected Congolese President.[http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=61666 "DRC: Supreme Court validates Kabila presidential victory"], IRIN, 28 November 2006. A day later, Bemba said that he disagreed with the court's decision, but that "in the greater national interest and to preserve peace and to save the country from chaos and violence", he would participate in the system by leading the political opposition.[http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=61677 "DRC: Bemba condemns poll ruling but ready to lead opposition"], IRIN, 28 November 2006.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6193384.stm "Bemba accepts DR Congo poll loss"], BBC News, 28 November 2006. He did not attend Kabila's swearing-in ceremony on 6 December. On 8 December, the MLC announced that Bemba would run for a Senate seat from Kinshasa in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo Senate election, 2007|January 2007 senatorial election]],[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=qw1165597020331R131 "Bemba to run for Senate"], AFP (''IOL''), 8 December 2006. and he succeeded in winning a seat.[http://english.people.com.cn/200701/21/eng20070121_343315.html "Former DR Congo vice president wins seat in Senate"], Xinhua (''People's Daily Online''), 21 January 2007. ==March 2007 violence== A further attempt on Bemba's life in March 2007 led to an outbreak of fighting near Bemba's residence.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070322153441459C201618 "Sustained gunfire reported in Congo's capital"], Associated Press (''IOL''), 22 March 2007. A number of soldiers and civilians were reported killed. Bemba called for a ceasefire and negotiations and took refuge in the [[South Africa]]n embassy.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6482997.stm "DR Congo rebel chief seeks refuge"], BBC News, 23 March 2007. As fighting continued on 23 March, it was announced that a warrant for Bemba's arrest had been issued, accusing him of high treason.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php "Bemba: Wanted for high treason"], Reuters (''IOL''), 23 March 2007.[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,260597,00.html "Warrant Issued for Former Warlord as Congo Fighting Continues"], Associated Press (FOX News), 23 March 2007. Although Bemba enjoyed immunity as a senator, the country's chief prosecutor said that he would ask parliament to remove it. On 26 March, Kabila said that security could not be guaranteed through negotiation and referred to the importance of restoring order. Bemba warned of a potential for dictatorship and forshadowed his retreat into exile, citing security concerns.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20070326220308692C333630 "Kabila defends use of force as clashes go on"], AFP (''IOL''), 26 March 2007. Late in the month it was reported that Bemba planned to travel to [[Portugal]] for treatment of a broken leg; he had already received treatment for his leg there in previous months. The Portuguese ambassador subsequently said on 30 March that Bemba was expected to go to Portugal for treatment, but was not going into exile there.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070330144757556C818465 "Portugal accepts Bemba but not for exile"], Reuters (''IOL''), 30 March 2007. On 9 April, the Senate approved the trip, for a period of 60 days.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E2B9F777-CE7B-4609-9AC3-EEA7892AE0F8.htm "Bemba 'free to leave' DR Congo"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930235933/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E2B9F777-CE7B-4609-9AC3-EEA7892AE0F8.htm |date=30 September 2007 }}, Al Jazeera, 10 April 2007.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20070411213756504C850579 "Bemba arrives in Portugal"], AFP (''IOL''), 12 April 2007. On 11 April, Bemba left the South African embassy and was taken to the airport by U.N. [[MONUC]] forces, then flown out of the country to Portugal,[https://web.archive.org/web/20070607150318/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/4C4B86F3-6AE2-464F-9987-F06A25171A7D.htm "Bemba leaves DR Congo"], Al Jazeera, 11 April 2007. along with his wife and children. On 12 April, the attorney general, Tshimanga Mukeba, said that he had asked the Senate to remove Bemba's immunity.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070412142618973C720095 "DRC seeks to lift Bemba's immunity"], DPA (''IOL''), 12 April 2007. Following the outbreak of violence in March, Bemba's party, the MLC, said that it was being targeted by the government through arrests and intimidation, and that its headquarters was occupied by government forces.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070408221612455C553348 "DRC opposition party hits out at government"], AFP (''IOL''), 9 April 2007. On 13 April, the party suspended its participation in the [[National Assembly of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|National Assembly]] due to this intimidation and insecurity.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070414150316673C333192 "Bemba's party concerned about security"], Reuters (''IOL''), 14 April 2007. In the first half of June, it was reported that, despite the expiration of the 60 days prescribed by the Senate, Bemba would not return to the DRC due to safety concerns.John James, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6738427.stm "DR Congo's Bemba to stay abroad"], BBC News, 10 June 2007. According to MLC executive secretary {{ILL|Thomas Luhaka|fr}}, Bemba was medically able to return and take part in politics again, and Luhaka called for a political solution to facilitate his return. Without Senate permission to be absent, he would automatically lose his seat if absent from over a quarter of Senate sessions, unless the absences were justified.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070611132105383C978936 "We want Bemba back, say DRC opposition"], AFP (''IOL''), 11 June 2007. On 15 June, the Senate extended Bemba's permitted absence until 31 July, following a request from Bemba in a 12 June letter in asking for more time. In this letter he expressed a readiness to return and take part in politics, but also expressed concerns about his safety.[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?art_cle=37420 "RDC: Jean-Pierre Bemba autorisé à prolonger son séjour au Portugal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185917/http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?art_cle=37420 |date=30 September 2007 }}, AFP (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), 15 June 2007 {{fr icon}}.[http://apanews.net/spip.php?page=show_article&id_article=35515 "Senate extends to 31 July Bemba’s stay in Portugal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529054930/http://apanews.net/spip.php?page=show_article&id_article=35515 |date=29 May 2008 }}, African Press Agency, 16 June 2007. On 13 July, Bemba met with [[Louis Michel]], the [[European Commissioner for Development & Humanitarian Aid]]. According to Michel, Bemba "intends to give the presidential majority the benefit of the doubt" and would not do or say anything "that could be taken as an attempt at destabilisation".[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20070714103826183C663305 "Bemba wants to return to DRC"], AFP (''IOL''), 14 July 2007. He did not return by the deadline on 31 July, with a spokesman citing continued security concerns; the Senate was then in recess until 15 September,Lubunga Bya'Ombe, [http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=nw20070731214612156C163557 "Bemba not ready to return to DRC"], Reuters (''IOL''), 1 August 2007. and Senate President [[Kengo wa Dondo]] said that Bemba would not be penalized for being away during this period because the Senate was not in session.[http://apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=38469 "DR Congo: Bemba’s sick leave expires abroad, but no penalty as senator"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529054823/http://apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=38469 |date=29 May 2008 }}, African Press Agency, 1 August 2007. In a statement published on 1 August, Bemba said that he wanted to return before 15 September.[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?reg_id=0&art_cle=38406 "Jean-Pierre Bemba souhaite revenir en RDC avant le 15 septembre"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183718/http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?reg_id=0&art_cle=38406 |date=30 September 2007 }}, AFP (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), 1 August 2007 {{fr icon}}. It was announced on 7 September that Bemba had met with National Assembly President [[Vital Kamerhe]] in Portugal to discuss his potential return.[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?reg_id=0&art_cle=39083 "Le président du parlement de RDCongo a rencontré Jean-Pierre Bemba au Portugal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910040055/http://www.jeuneafrique.com/fluxafp/fil_info.asp?reg_id=0&art_cle=39083 |date=10 September 2007 }}, AFP (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), 7 September 2007 {{fr icon}}. In November 2007, he visited [[Belgium]] and met with Belgian Foreign Minister [[Karel De Gucht]] on 5 November.[http://www.afriquechos.ch/spip.php?article2621 "Jean-Pierre Bemba en visite « privée » en Belgique depuis plusieurs jours"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531173226/http://www.afriquechos.ch/spip.php?article2621 |date=31 May 2008 }}, afriquechos.ch, 7 November 2007 {{fr icon}}. In a March 2008 interview, Bemba said that he was in "forced exile" and that it seemed the government was moving towards a dictatorship.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=136&art_id=nw20080322120854845C401296 "'DRC slipping into dictatorship'"], Sapa-AFP (''IOL''), 22 March 2008. ==Arrest and trial== [[File:J.P.BembaPoster.JPG|thumb|right|Poster announcing a protest in [[Brussels]] to support Bemba after his arrest.]] In March 2003, Central African president [[Ange-Félix Patassé]] was ousted, and the government that replaced him pressed charges against Patassé and Bemba in September 2004. International arrest warrants were issued, but because the new government was unable to have Bemba arrested, the matter was referred to the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC). On 22 May 2007, ICC prosecutor [[Luis Moreno-Ocampo]] decided to open investigations into crimes committed in the [[Central African Republic]].{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2007/05/22/carepu15980.htm|title=Central African Republic: ICC Opens Investigation (Human Rights Watch, 22-5-2007)|publisher=}} On 23 May 2008, a pre-trial chamber of the ICC found that there were reasonable grounds to believe that Bemba bore individual criminal responsibility for [[war crime]]s and [[crime against humanity|crimes against humanity]] committed in the Central African Republic between 25 October 2002 and 15 March 2003, and issued a sealed warrant for his arrest. He was charged with five counts of war crimes ([[murder]], [[rape]], [[torture]], [[pillaging]], and outrages upon personal dignity) and three counts of crimes against humanity (murder, rape and torture). On 24 May 2008, Bemba was arrested near [[Brussels]].[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-05/25/content_8248030.htm "Former Congo rebel leader arrested for war crimes"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528150320/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-05/25/content_8248030.htm |date=28 May 2008 }}, Xinhua, 25 May 2008.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7418932.stm "Former DR Congo leader arrested"], BBC World News, 24 May 2008. He was handed over to the ICC on 3 July 2008 and transferred to its detention centre in the Hague.International Criminal Court (3 July 2008). ''[http://www.icc-cpi.int/press/pressreleases/395.html Surrender of Jean-Pierre Bemba to the International Criminal Court] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708111527/http://www.icc-cpi.int/press/pressreleases/395.html |date=8 July 2008 }}''. Retrieved on 3 July 2008. He was the only person arrested in connection with the ICC's investigation in the Central African Republic. The Supreme Court of the Central African Republic found no basis to pursue cases against Bemba and former CAR President [[Ange-Félix Patassé]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6679513.stm "Hague court probes CAR 'crimes'"], BBC World News, 22 May 2007. The MLC denounced the arrest and requested that Parliament do likewise; it also asked that Parliament call on the Belgian government to respect Bemba's immunity as a senator under Congolese law. MLC official {{ILL|Delly Sesanga|fr}} accused ICC prosecutor Moreno-Ocampo of trying "to interfere with the internal businesses of Congo", describing such interference as "unacceptable"; Sesanga also said that, although the prosecution claimed Bemba was a flight risk, there had been no indication of that. More than 2,000 supporters of Bemba protested in Kinshasa on 27 May, demanding that he be freed.[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20080528055308742C226180 "Uproar in DRC after Bemba is arrested"], ''The Star'' (''IOL''), 28 May 2008, page 4. Bemba's defense argued that the legal procedures applied to Bemba's case were irregular, but on 1 July a Belgian court rejected this argument, making it possible to transfer Bemba to the ICC. Meanwhile, MLC official Fyfy Osambia argued that "the matter has been politicised" and that people "close to President Kabila" were responsible for the complaint against Bemba. He said that Bemba should be allowed to go before the ICC without being a prisoner.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iH3_oKv2qGOw-Z5mSSXcXXdh4SkA "Belgian court clears way for Bemba transfer to war crimes court"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707123918/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iH3_oKv2qGOw-Z5mSSXcXXdh4SkA |date=7 July 2009 }}, AFP, 1 July 2008. Following the Belgian court ruling, Bemba was transferred to the ICC in [[The Hague]] on 3 July. In a hearing on 4 July, Bemba made his first appearance at the ICC, and the beginning of a hearing dealing with confirmation of the charges against him was set for 4 November. On 15 June 2009, an ICC pre-trial chamber confirmed some of the charges against Bemba and committed him to trial.International Criminal Court (15 June 2009). [http://www2.icc-cpi.int/menus/icc/situations%20and%20cases/situations/situation%20icc%200105/related%20cases/icc%200105%200108/press%20releases/20090615pr421 ''Pre-Trial Chamber II commits Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo to trial''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125175314/http://icc-cpi.int/menus/icc/situations%20and%20cases/situations/situation%20icc%200105/related%20cases/icc%200105%200108/press%20releases/20090615pr421 |date=25 November 2010 }}. Retrieved on 12 July 2009. However, the judges did not find that there was sufficient evidence to try him for torture and outrages upon personal dignity. On 8 July 2009, Bemba was granted a temporary release to attend his father's funeral in Brussels."[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i87p26ASg1UphL3uFAe7XarK30yA Former Congo VP attends funeral ahead of war crimes trial]". [[Agence France-Presse]] (8 July 2009). Retrieved 12 July 2009. On 2 December 2009 the ICC ruled that Bemba was a flight risk and must remain in custody until his trial.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/articles/120/article_6059.asp|title=RFI - ICC rule that Bemba must stay in custody|publisher=}} The trial of Bemba began on 22 November 2010{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201011191101.html|title=Central Africa: The Trial of Jean-Pierre Bemba|date=19 November 2010|publisher=|via=AllAfrica}}{{cite web|url=http://networkedblogs.com/aSU4Z|title=War crimes trial of Congolese militia leader begins at International Criminal Court|publisher=}} and lasted four years. The prosecutor was [[Fatou Bensouda]]. Two more years passed before the verdict was given. On 21 March 2016, he was convicted on two counts of crimes against humanity and three counts of war crimes.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/21/icc-finds-ex-congolese-vice-president-jean-pierre-bemba-guilty-of-war-crimes|title=Congo politician guilty in first ICC trial to focus on rape as a war crime|publisher=The Guardian|date=21 March 2016|accessdate=22 March 2016}} This marked the first time the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC) convicted someone of sexual violence.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/international-court-adds-rape-to-war-crimes-list-in-congo-conviction/2016/03/21/2e7f4320-ef72-11e5-85a6-2132cf446d0a_story.html|title=In historic ruling, international court cites rape in war crimes conviction of ex-Congo official|author=Kevin Sieff|date=21 March 2016|work=Washington Post}} On 21 June 2016, the ICC sentenced Bemba to 18 years in prison for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by his Congolese Liberation Movement (MLC).{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/06/21/Former-Congo-vice-president-Jean-Pierre-Bemba-sentenced-to-18-years-for-war-crimes |title=Former Congo vice-president Jean-Pierre Bemba sentenced to 18 years for war crimes |publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)|''The Times'']] |date=21 June 2016 |accessdate=21 June 2016}} In March 2017 he was sentenced to an extra year in prison and fined 300,000 euros ($324,000) by the ICC for interfering with witnesses in his trial.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/03/22/icc-gives-former-congo-vp-bemba-extra-year-in-prison.html|title=ICC gives former Congo VP Bemba extra year in prison|publisher=Fox News|date=22 March 2017}} ==Conviction overturned== On 28 September 2016, Bemba served the ICC appeals chamber with an appeal against his 18-year conviction citing numerous procedural and legal errors in the judgment, and alleging a mistrial. This conviction was overturned on 8 June 2018{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/jun/08/former-congo-leader-jean-pierre-bemba-wins-war-crimes-appeal-international-criminal-court|title=Jean-Pierre Bemba's war crimes conviction overturned|last=Bowcott|first=Owen|date=2018-06-08|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-11}} by Judge [[Christine Van den Wyngaert]]. She said he cannot be held responsible for the actions of his men, and that the lower court "ignored significant testimonial evidence that Bemba's ability to investigate and punish crimes in the CAR was limited".{{cite web|publisher=BBC |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-44418154 |title=Jean-Pierre Bemba: Congo warlord's conviction overturned |date=8 June 2018}} On 4 May 2017 he had also filed an appeal against his conviction for interfering with witnesses, alleging factual and legal errors on the part of the trial chamber, and illegal investigative activity by the ICC Office of the Prosecutor.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} On 1 August 2018, Bemba returned to the DRC after 11 years of exile and imprisonment.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-45031572|title=DR Congo crowds welcome ex-warlord|date=2018-08-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-GB}} On 1 August 2018, Jean-Pierre Bemba returned to DR Congo from prison to run for president.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/01/former-dr-congo-rebel-presidential-bid-jean-pierre-bemba|title=Former warlord returns to DR Congo from prison to run for president|last=Burke|first=Jason|date=2018-08-01|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}} Bemba is running for [[President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2018|2018 election]], and is considered to be the strongest opposition candidate. As of August 2018, his candidacy is being reviewed by the country's [[Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|Independent National Electoral Commission]]. == Notes and references == {{reflist}} == Further reading == *{{cite journal |last=O'Regan |first=Fiona |year=2012 |title=''Prosecutor vs. Jean-Pierre Bemba Gombo'': The Cumulative Charging Principle, Gender-Based Violence, and Expressivism |journal=Georgetown Journal of International Law |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=1323–1360 |issn=1550-5200 }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[https://archive.is/20120526203820/http://www.icc-cpi.int/Menus/ICC/Situations+and+Cases/Situations/Situation+ICC+0105/Related+Cases/ICC+0105+0108/Case+The+Prosecutor+v+Jean-Pierre+Bemba+Gombo.htm ICC Website for Jean-Pierre Bemba] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dk6xmIuwGEo Al Jazeera interview with Bemba, 3 August 2007.] {{2006 presidential election candidates, Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{ICC indictees (NavBox)}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bemba, Jean-Pierre}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Nord-Ubangi]] [[Category:Vice-Presidents of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Movement for the Liberation of the Congo politicians]] [[Category:Candidates for President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:21st-century criminals]] [[Category:Rebels]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo people convicted of crimes against humanity]] [[Category:People extradited from Belgium]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo people convicted of war crimes]] [[Category:People convicted by the International Criminal Court]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo politicians convicted of crimes]]

{{pp|small=yes}} {{For|the American astronaut|Kenneth Ham}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Ken Ham | other_names = | image = KenHam.JPG | image_size = | caption = Ken Ham in 2012 | birth_name = Kenneth Alfred Ham | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1951|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Cairns|Cairns, Queensland]], Australia | nationality = Australian | residence = United States of America | known = | occupation = [[Young Earth creationist]], [[Christian apologetics|Christian apologist]],
[[Evangelism|Evangelist]] | title = [[Organizational founder|Founder]], [[President (corporate title)|President]], [[CEO]] | organization = [[Answers in Genesis]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Marylin Ham | children = 5 | alma_mater = [[Queensland Institute of Technology]] ([[Bachelor of Applied Science|B.AS.]])
[[University of Queensland]] | relations = | website = {{url|http://www.answersingenesis.org}} | footnotes = | employer = }} '''Kenneth Alfred Ham''' (born 20 October 1951) is an Australian-born [[Christian fundamentalism|Christian fundamentalist]] and [[Young Earth creationism|young Earth creationist]] living in the United States. He is the president of [[Answers in Genesis]] (AiG), a [[creationist apologetics]] organization that operates the [[Creation Museum]] and the [[Ark Encounter]]. Ham advocates [[biblical literalism]], believing that the [[Book of Genesis]] is historical fact and the universe is approximately 6,000 years old,{{refn|group=n|name=Note1|In ''How Do We Know the Bible is True?'' Ham and Hodge wrote: "The biblical age of the earth is determined by adding up the genealogies from Adam ...to Christ. This is about 4000 years...Christ lived about 2000 years ago, so this gives us about 6000 years as the biblical age of the earth." (p. 110). "I hold to that belief because I trust the Bible over the reasoning of man." (p. 109). "Some mainstream scientists have calculated the age of the earth at approximately 4.5 billion years... Rejecting literal days of creation naturally leads to the acceptance of the supposed big bang as the evolutionary method God used to create the universe. Although we can simply add up the ages of the patriarch mentioned in the Genesis 5 and 11 genealogies to arrive at a date after creation for Abraham who lived about 4000 years ago, many reject this as a reasonable way of determining the timing of creation." (p. 110). "Surely God is free to accomplish miracles within the world He created, so this should not be a problem for those who believe what God has revealed through the Scriptures. But neither should creating the universe in six days or causing the entire globe to be flooded..." (p. 113).{{cite book |last1= Ham |first1= Ken |last2= Hodge |first2= Bodie |title= How Do We Know the Bible is True? |year= 2012 |location= Green Forest, AR |publisher= [[Institute for Creation Research|New Leaf]] |isbn= 9780890516614 |pages= [https://books.google.com/books?id=vqh7yUCgEGcC&pg=PA108 108–10]}}}} contrary to multiple individual lines of [[scientific evidence]] which show the [[age of the Earth|Earth]] is about 4.5 billion years old and [[age of the universe|the universe]] is about 13.8 billion years old.{{cite web| date=1997 | title=Age of the Earth| url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/geotime/age.html | publisher=U.S. Geological Survey | accessdate=10 January 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051223072700/http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/geotime/age.html| archivedate= 23 December 2005 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url= http://www.astro.ucla.edu/~wright/age.html |title=Age of the Universe |first= |last= |work=astro.ucla.edu |year=2012 |accessdate=15 May 2014}} ==Early life== Ham was born 20 October 1951 in [[Cairns]], Australia.{{cite book|last=Communications|first=Emmis|title=Cincinnati Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7u0CAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80 |date=October 1998|publisher=Emmis Communications|pages=80– |accessdate=10 May 2014}} His father, Mervyn, was a Christian educator who served as a school principal in several schools throughout [[Queensland]].Ham, K. & Ham, S. (2008), ''Raising Godly Children in an Ungodly World: Leaving a Lasting Legacy'', New Leaf Publishing Group {{ISBN|9781614580720}}{{cite book |last1=Trollinger |first1=Susan L. |last2=Trollinger Jr. |first2=William Vance |title=Righting America at the Creation Museum |publisher=JHU Press |year=2016 |isbn=9781421419534 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lOf-CwAAQBAJ |page=9}} Ham earned a [[Bachelor of Applied Science]], with an emphasis in [[Environmental Biology]] at [[Queensland Institute of Technology]] and a Diploma in Education from the [[University of Queensland]].{{cite book |last1=Stephens |first1=Randall J. |last2=Giberson |first2=Karl |title=The Anointed: Evangelical Truth in a Secular Age |year=2011 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=VKyCOhWWHD8C&pg=PA11 11]}} See also listing at [https://books.google.com/books?id=VKyCOhWWHD8C&q=Queensland+Institute#v=snippet&q=Queensland%20Institute&f=false Google Books.] While at university, he was influenced by [[John C. Whitcomb]] and [[Henry M. Morris]]'s 1961 book ''[[The Genesis Flood: The Biblical Record and Its Scientific Implications|The Genesis Flood]]''. Upon graduation in 1975, Ham began teaching science at a high school in [[Dalby, Queensland]]. ==Career== {{See also|Answers in Genesis|Creation Museum}} In 1977, Ham began teaching at a high school in [[Brisbane]] where he met John Mackay, another teacher who believed in young Earth creationism. According to Susan and William Trollinger, Ham was "appalled by the fact that some of his students assumed their textbooks that taught evolutionary science successfully proved the Bible to be untrue," and he said the experience "put a 'fire in my bones' to do something about the influence that evolutionary thinking was having on students and the public as a whole." In 1979, he resigned his teaching position and, with his wife, founded Creation Science Supplies and Creation Science Educational Media Services, which provided resources for the teaching of creationism in the public schools of Queensland, a practice allowed at the time.https://journeyonline.com.au/features/ken-ham-queenslander-answers/ In 1980, the Hams and Mackay merged the two organizations with [[Carl Wieland]]'s Creation Science Association to form the Creation Science Foundation (CSF).{{cite news |last1=Bromley |first1=David G. |last2=Duke |first2=Merin |last3=Bhatt |first3=Simren |title=Answers in Genesis |work=World Religions and Spirituality Project |publisher=Virginia Commonwealth University |date=27 February 2015 |url=http://www.wrs.vcu.edu/profiles/AnswersInGenesis.htm |accessdate=6 June 2016}} [[File:Ken Ham.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Ham speaking at the Creation Museum in 2014]] As CSF's work expanded, Ham moved to the United States in January 1987 to engage in speaking tours with another young Earth creationist organization, the [[Institute for Creation Research]] (ICR).{{cite web |url= http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/organizations/#creation |title= Creation/Evolution Organizations: Creationist and Anti-Evolutionist Organizations |publisher= [[TalkOrigins Archive]] |website= talkorigins.org |last= Hopkins |first= Michael |date= 9 October 2006}} His "Back to Genesis" lecture series focused on three major themes – that [[evolutionary theory]] had led to cultural decay, that a literal reading of the first eleven chapters of the [[Book of Genesis]] contained the true [[origin of the universe]] and a pattern for society, and that Christians should engage in a culture war against [[atheism]] and [[secular humanism|humanism]].{{cite book |last1=Trollinger |first1=Susan L. |last2=Trollinger Jr. |first2=William Vance |title=Righting America at the Creation Museum |publisher=JHU Press |year=2016 |isbn=9781421419534 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lOf-CwAAQBAJ |page=10}} With his popularity growing in the United States, Ham left ICR in 1994 and, with colleagues Mark Looy and Mike Zovath, founded Creation Science Ministries with the assistance of what is now [[Creation Ministries International]] (Australia).{{cite web |url= http://www.answersingenesis.org/about/history |title= The History of AiG through mid 2009 |last= Ham |first= Ken |website= answersingenesis.org |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090901150841/http://www.answersingenesis.org/about/history |archivedate= 1 September 2009}}{{cite episode |url= http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2005/s1501593.htm |series= [[Lateline]] |title= The great debate |network= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date= 9 November 2005 |first= Mark |last= Simkin |accessdate= 17 March 2011}} In 1997, Ham's organization changed its name to [[Answers in Genesis]]. From the time AiG was founded, Ham planned to open a museum and training center near its headquarters in [[Florence, Kentucky]], telling an [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] interviewer in 2007, "Australia's not really the place to build such a facility if you're going to reach the world. Really, America is."{{cite news|last = Eigelbach|first = Kevin|title = Creating Debate – Answers in Genesis Opens its Museum Monday as a Challenge to Darwinism|date = 25 May 2007|newspaper = The Kentucky Post|page = A1}}Kim Landers, "[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2007/s1936088.htm Museum promotes creationism]", AM, [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], 29 May 2007. In a separate interview with ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'''s [[Paul Sheehan (journalist)|Paul Sheehan]], Ham explained, "One of the main reasons [AiG] moved [to Florence] was because we are within one hour's flight of 69 percent of America's population."[[Paul Sheehan (journalist)|Paul Sheehan]], "[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2005/01/16/1105810774805.html Onward the new Christian soldier]", ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', [[Sydney, Australia]], 17 January 2005. The {{convert|60000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} museum, located in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]], {{convert|4|mi|km}} west of the [[Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport]], opened 27 May 2007.{{Cite news|last = Kreimer|first = Peggy|title = Creation Museum's Pitch Drawing Headlines, Barbs|newspaper = The Kentucky Post|date = 4 February 2005|page = K1}} In February 2018, Ham was disinvited from the [[University of Central Oklahoma]], where he was scheduled to speak, after an LGBTQ student group objected.{{cite web | last1=Hinton | first1=Carla | title=UCO Student Group Rescinds Invitation to Christian Speaker Ken Ham | url=http://newsok.com/uco-student-group-rescinds-invitation-to-christian-speaker-ken-ham/article/5582635 | date=February 8, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Oklahoman]]'' | accessdate=February 8, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Causey | first1=Adam Kealoha | title=Creationist's Speech Canceled at University in Oklahoma | url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/education/article/Creationist-s-speech-canceled-at-university-in-12563015.php | date=February 8, 2018 | publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' (from the [[Associated Press]]) | accessdate=February 8, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Kocher | first1=Greg | title=He Got Creation Museum, Ark Built in Kentucky, but He Can’t Speak on Oklahoma Campus | url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article199339969.html | date=February 9, 2018 | publisher=''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' | accessdate=February 11, 2018}} Later that month, UCO reinvited Ham to speak,{{cite web | last1=Hinton | first1=Carla | title=Ken Ham Will Speak on UCO Campus After All | url=http://newsok.com/ken-ham-will-speak-on-uco-campus-after-all/article/5583535 | date=February 15, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Oklahoman]]'' | accessdate=February 15, 2018}}{{cite web | title=Creationist’s Speech Back On at University in Oklahoma | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/creationists-speech-back-on-at-university-in-oklahoma/2018/02/15/811158b8-1279-11e8-a68c-e9374188170e_story.html | date=February 15, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' (from the [[Associated Press]]) | accessdate=February 15, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Stunson | first1=Mike | title=Here’s How Kentucky’s Creation Museum Chief Got a New Invite to Off-Limits Campus | url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article200314879.html | date=February 15, 2018 | publisher=''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' | accessdate=February 15, 2018}} and Ham spoke on March 5 as planned.{{cite web | last1=Willert | first1=Tom | title=UCO Speaker Draws Largely Friendly Crowd | url=http://newsok.com/uco-speaker-draws-largely-friendly-crowd/article/5585846 | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Oklahoman]]'' | accessdate=March 15, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Ross | first1=Bobby | title=After a Rescinded Invitation, Ken Ham Talks About God at an Oklahoma University | url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/900012189/after-a-rescinded-invitation-ken-ham-talks-about-god-at-an-oklahoma-university.html | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[Deseret News]]'' (from [[Religion News Service]]) | accessdate=March 15, 2018}} ==Disputes with CMI and GHC== At the end of 2005, the AiG Confederation crumbled due to a disagreement between Ham and Carl Wieland over the "differences in philosophy and operation". This disagreement led to Ham effectively retaining the leadership of the UK and American branches whilst Wieland served as managing director of the Australian branch and the smaller offices in Canada, New Zealand, and South Africa. This splitting into two groups led to the Australian branch renaming themselves Creation Ministries International (CMI). The AiG stayed with Ham and continued to expand its staff and work closely with the Institute for Creation Research (ICR). Young Earth creationist [[Kurt Wise]] was recruited by Ham as a consultant to help with the concluding phases of the museum project.Numbers, Ron (2006) The Creationists In May 2007, [[Creation Ministries International#Legal controversy with Answers In Genesis|Creation Ministries International]] (CMI) [[Answers in Genesis#Legal action by Creation Ministries International|filed a lawsuit against Ham and AiG]] in the [[Supreme Court of Queensland]] seeking damages and accusing him of deceptive conduct in his dealings with the Australian organization. Members of the group expressed "concern over Mr. Ham's domination of the groups, the amount of money being spent on his fellow executives and a shift away from delivering the creationist message to raising donations."{{cite news|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070728091913/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C20867%2C21843706-2702%2C00.html?from=public_rss |archivedate=28 July 2007 |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21843706-2702,00.html?from=public_rss |title=Biblical battle of creation groups |newspaper=[[The Australian]] |date=4 June 2007 |first=Michael |last=McKenna |deadurl=yes |df= }} Ham was accused of trying to send the Australian ministry into [[bankruptcy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/biblical-battle-of-creation-groups/story-e6frg6nf-1111113672622|title=Biblical battle of creation groups|publisher=}} According to the CMI website, this dispute was amicably settled in April 2009.{{cite web |url= http://creation.com/dispute-settled |title= Dispute Settled |publisher= [[Creation Ministries International]] |website= creation.com |accessdate= 6 April 2010}} In 2008, Ham appeared in [[Bill Maher]]'s comedy-documentary ''[[Religulous]]''.{{cite news |url= http://www.charlotteobserver.com/104/story/226061.html |title= Maher takes on religion, but some interviewees cry foul |newspaper= [[Charlotte Observer]] |date= 1 October 2008 |first= Rebecca |last= Cusey |accessdate= 4 October 2008 | archivedate= 27 September 2013 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130927073007/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2008/10/01/226061/maher-takes-on-religion-but-some.html}} AiG criticized the movie for what it called Maher's "dishonesty last year in gaining access to the [[Creation Museum]] and AiG President Ken Ham."{{cite web |url= http://www.answersingenesis.org/articles/2008/10/02/a-religulous-movie |title= A Religulous Movie: Opens on 500 Screens Friday—Creation Museum mocked |website= answersingenesis.org |publisher= [[Answers in Genesis]] |date= 2 October 2008 |first= Melany |last= Ethridge |accessdate= 4 October 2008}} In March 2011, the board of Great Homeschool Conventions, Inc. (GHC) voted to disinvite Ham and AiG from future conventions. Conference organizer Brennan Dean stated Ham had made "unnecessary, ungodly, and mean-spirited statements that are divisive at best and defamatory at worst". Dean stated further, "We believe Christian scholars should be heard without the fear of [[ostracism]] or [[ad hominem]] attacks."{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2011/marchweb-only/kenhamhomeschool.html|title=Conference Disinvites Ken Ham|publisher=}} The disinvitation occurred after Ham criticized [[Peter Enns]] of [[The BioLogos Foundation]], who advocated a symbolic, rather than literal, interpretation of the fall of Adam and Eve. Ham accused Enns of espousing "outright liberal theology that totally undermines the authority of the Word of God".{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |date=24 March 2011 |title=Founder of Creation Museum banned from convention |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/kentucky/article44085801.html |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |location=Sacramento, CA |publisher=The McClatchy Company |accessdate=10 October 2014}} ==Bill Nye–Ken Ham debate== {{Main|Bill Nye–Ken Ham debate}} In February 2014, Ham debated American [[science educator]] and [[engineer]] [[Bill Nye]] (popularly known as "[[Bill Nye the Science Guy]]") on the topic of whether young Earth creationism is a viable model of origins in the contemporary scientific era.{{cite web |last=Boyle|first=Alan |title=Bill Nye Wins Over the Science Crowd at Evolution Debate|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/bill-nye-wins-over-science-crowd-evolution-debate-n22836|work=[[NBC News]] |date=5 February 2014 |accessdate=6 February 2014 }} Critics expressed concern that the debate lent the appearance of scientific legitimacy to creationism while also stimulating Ham's fundraising.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2014/feb/05/bill-nye-vs-ken-ham-creationism-science-debate |title= Bill Nye v Ken Ham: Should scientists bother to debate creationism? The public debate between Bill Nye and the president of a US creationist museum gives creationism a scientific legitimacy that it isn't entitled to. |department= Science |first= Pete |last= Etchells |date= 5 February 2014 |accessdate= 13 April 2014}}{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-cesca/creation-museum-demands-e_b_5031550.html |title= 'Creation Museum' Demands Equal Airtime to Refute Scientific Facts in Cosmos Series |first=Bob |last= Cesca |date= 25 March 2014 |work= [[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate= 13 April 2014}} Nye said the debate was "an opportunity to expose the well-intending Ken Ham and the support he receives from his followers as being bad for Kentucky, bad for science education, bad for the U.S., and thereby bad for humankind."{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/14/bill-nye-debate-creationist-ken-ham_n_5147775.html |title=Bill Nye Explains Why He Agreed To Debate Creationist Ken Ham |first=David |last=Freedman |date=14 April 2013 |work= [[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate= 16 April 2014}} Nye wrote his thoughts about the debate in ''[[Undeniable: Evolution and the Science of Creation]]''. {{cite book|last1=Nye|first1=Bill|title=Undeniable: Evolution and the Science of Creation|date=2014|publisher=St Martin's Press|isbn=1250007135|pages=9}} Ham said that publicity generated by the debate helped stimulate construction of the [[Ark Encounter]] theme park, which had been stalled for lack of funds.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/28/creation-museum-kentucky-noahs-ark-museum-ken-ham |title= Creation Museum's $73m Noah's Ark park to begin construction in Kentucky |department= World news |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= 28 February 2014 |accessdate= 13 April 2014}} The Ark Encounter opened on 7 July 2016, a date (7/7) chosen to correspond with Genesis 7:7, the Bible verse that describes Noah entering the ark.{{cite web |last=Pilcher |first=James |title=Answers in Genesis' Ark Encounter announces opening date |newspaper=The Cincinnati Enquirer |date=12 November 2015 |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/arkencounter/2015/11/11/answers-genesis-ark-encounter-opening-date-announcement-coming-thursday/75586608/ |accessdate=12 November 2015}} The following day, Nye visited Ark Encounter, and he and Ham had an informal debate.{{cite web |last1=Nye|first1=Bill |last2=Ham |first2=Ken |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Nye/Ham: The Second Debate Premiere (video - 117:04)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPLRhVdNp5M |date=13 March 2017 |work=[[YouTube]]}} [[File:AIG museum.jpg|thumb|right|275px|[[Creation Museum]] in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]]]] ==Creationist beliefs== According to Ham, he was inspired by his father, also a young Earth creationist, to interpret the Book of Genesis as "literal history" and first rejected what he termed "molecules-to-man evolution" during high school. As a [[Young Earth creationism|young Earth creationist]] and [[Biblical inerrancy|biblical inerrantist]], Ham believes that the [[Book of Genesis]] is historical fact. Ham believes the [[age of the Universe]] to be about 6,000 years{{refn|group=n|name=Note1}} and asserts that [[Noah's flood]] occurred about 4,400 years ago in approximately 2348 BC.{{cite web |last= Wright |first= David |title= Feedback: Timeline for the Flood |url= http://www.answersingenesis.org/articles/2012/03/09/feedback-timeline-for-the-flood |publisher= [[Answers in Genesis]] |website= answersingenesis.org |accessdate= 11 April 2012}} (Astrophysical measurements and [[radiometric dating]] show that the [[age of the universe]] is about 13.8 billion years and the [[age of the Earth]] is about 4.5 billion years.) Arguing that knowledge of [[evolution]] and the [[Big Bang]] require [[Cosmic microwave background|observation]] rather than [[inference]], Ham urges asking scientists and science educators, "Were you there?"{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2015/05/creationism_and_evolution_in_school_religious_students_can_t_learn_natural.html|title=Were You There?|first=Vanessa|last=Wamsley|date=26 May 2015|publisher=|via=Slate}}{{cite web |url= http://www.icr.org/index.php?module=articles&action=view&ID=670 |title= Were You There? |first= Kenneth |last= Ham |website= icr.org |publisher= [[Institute for Creation Research]]}} The [[Talk.origins]] archive responds that the evidence for evolution "was there," and that knowledge serves to determine what occurred in the past and when. "Were you there?" questions also invalidate creationism as science—an argument with which Ham himself agrees.{{cite web |url= http://www.talkorigins.org/indexcc/CA/CA221.html |title= Claim CA221: Were you there? |website= talkorigins.org |publisher= [[TalkOrigins Archive]] |date= 10 May 2004|accessdate= 15 April 2014}}https://books.google.com/books?id=dGFJXLEWogEC&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=%22were+you+there%22+evolution+responses&source=bl&ots=Vt8vkBGWYJ&sig=52VrtyWxkgEGPmfBg36VIQyG8G8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwimis3JsdTZAhUp7oMKHer9Cfs4ChDoAQguMAE#v=onepage&q=%22were%20you%20there%22%20evolution%20responses&f=false[https://answersingenesis.org/the-word-of-god/were-you-there/ Answers in Genesis website.] ==Reception== [[Chris Mooney (journalist)|Chris Mooney]], of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' magazine, believes Ham's advocacy of Young Earth Creation will "undermine [[science education]] and U.S. [[science literacy]]."{{cite news |url= http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/climate_desk/2014/04/your_inner_fish_book_and_pbs_documentary_on_tiktaalik_and_neil_shubin.html?wpisrc=burger_bar |title= Your Inner Fish: Book and PBS documentary on Tiktaalik and Neil Shubin |first= Chris |last= Mooney |date= 12 April 2014 |magazine= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |accessdate= 13 April 2014}} But Andrew O'Hehir of [[Salon (website)|''Salon'']] argues that the "liberal intelligentsia" have grossly overstated the influence of Ken Ham and those espousing similar views because, while "religious ecstasy, however nonsensical, is powerful in a way reason and logic are not," advocates like Ham "represent a [[marginalized]] constituency with little power."{{cite news |url=http://www.salon.com/2014/04/12/america_stupidly_stuck_between_religion_and_science/ |title= America: Stupidly stuck between religion and science |first= Andrew |last= O'Hehir |magazine= [[Salon (website)|''Salon'']] |date=12 April 2014 |accessdate= 16 April 2014}} Ham has been awarded [[honorary degree|honorary]] degrees by six Christian colleges: Temple Baptist College (1997),{{cite web |last=Stear |first=Mary Anne |title=The Future of Natural History The Creation Museum and the Young Earth Creationism Bid for Scientific Proof |publisher=Illinois State University |page=16 |url=http://soa.illinoisstate.edu/downloads/TheFutureofnNaturalHistoryTheCreationMuseumAndTheYoungEarthCreationismBidForScientificProof..doc |accessdate=24 June 2015}} [[Liberty University]] (2004),{{cite book |last=Stephens |first=Randall J. |author2=Giberson, Karl |title=The Anointed: Evangelical Truth in a Secular Age |publisher=Harvard University Press |year=2011 |isbn=0674048180 |page=42}} [[Tennessee Temple University]] (2010),{{cite web |title=Graduation DVD |publisher=Tennessee Temple University |url=http://www.tntemple.edu/graduation-dvd |accessdate=24 June 2015}} [[Mid-Continent University]] (2012),{{cite news |last=Egan |first=Corianne |title=Creationist talks to Heartland crowd |newspaper=The Paducah Sun |location=Paducah, Kentucky |date=6 March 2012 |page=2A |url=http://www.paducahsun.com/assets/10582673/06032012_a.pdf |accessdate=24 June 2015}} [[Bryan College]] (2017),{{cite web | last1=Jolley | first1=Curtis | title=Ken Ham Receives Honorary Doctorate At Bryan College Spring Graduation Ceremony | url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2017/5/11/347870/Ken-Ham-Receives-Honorary-Doctorate.aspx | date=11 May 2017 | publisher=''[[The Chattanoogan]]'' | accessdate=11 May 2017}} and [[Mid-America Baptist Theological Seminary]] (2018).{{cite web | title=Founders’ Days | Day 2 | Convocation | url=https://vimeo.com/286213009 | date=August 22, 2018 | publisher=[[Mid-America Baptist Theological Seminary]] (through [[Vimeo]]) | accessdate=September 7, 2018}} ==Personal life== Ham is married to Marylin Ham; the couple have five children and sixteen grandchildren.{{cite web |url= http://www.answersingenesis.org/outreach/speakers/ken-ham/bio/ |title= Ken Ham |publisher= [[Answers in Genesis]] |website= answersingensis.org}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox LGBT rights | location_header = Papua New Guinea | image = LocationPapuaNewGuinea.png | caption = [[Papua New Guinea]] | legal_status = Male illegal, female legal | penalty = Up to 14 years imprisonment ([[unenforced law|not enforced]]) | gender_identity_expression = – }}
'''Lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT)''' persons in '''Papua New Guinea''' face legal challenges not experienced by non-[[LGBT]] residents. Male same-sex sexual activity is illegal.
Attitudes towards LGBT people are greatly influenced by Christian churches, as a majority of Papua New Guineans are Christian. Historically, gay men had certain societal roles. They would take on traditional female roles such as cooking and would participate with women in traditional festivals. However, some tribes still practice ritual pedophilic homosexuality such as the [[Etoro people]] and [[Sambia people]].<ref name=gilesreview>{{cite journal |last=Giles |first=James |date=August 2004 |title=Book Reviews Sambia Sexual Culture: Essays From the Field. By Gilbert Herdt. University of Chicago Press, Chicago, Illinois, 1999, 327 pp., $20.00. |journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior |volume=33 |issue=4 |pages=413–417 |doi=10.1023/b:aseb.0000029074.36846.30}}</ref>
Nowadays, LGBT people tend to more tolerated and accepted in coastal areas than in the [[New Guinea Highlands]].<ref name="png">[http://www.vladsokhin.com/work/being-gay-in-papua-new-guinea/#1 Being Gay in Papua New Guinea]</ref>
==Terminology== The words "lesbian", "gay", "bisexual" and "transgender" tend to carry heavy stigma in Papua New Guinea.<ref name="culture">[https://rainbowpng.wordpress.com/2016/10/28/reclaiming-our-rainbow-cultural-identities/ Reclaiming our rainbow cultural identities]</ref>
In recent years, the [[Tok Pisin]] word ''palopa'' has been used by transgender Papua New Guineas to refer to a cultural and traditional third gender. Similarly, the [[Sambia people]] recognize a traditional third gender: ''kwolu-aatmwol'' (literally ''male thing transforming into female thing'').<ref name="culture"/>
==Legality of same-sex sexual activity== [[File:LGBT flag map of Papua New Guinea.svg|thumb|right|LGBT flag map of Papua New Guinea]] Male same-sex sexual activity is prohibited by Section 210 of the [[Papua New Guinea]] Penal Code. Those caught engaging in [[anal sex]] can get punished with up to fourteen years imprisonment. Other same-sex sexual acts can be punished with up to three years imprisonment.<ref>[http://old.ilga.org/Statehomophobia/ILGA_State_Sponsored_Homophobia_2013.pdf State-sponsored Homophobia A world survey of laws prohibiting same sex activity between consenting adults] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6IEmVxpKn?url=http://old.ilga.org/Statehomophobia/ILGA_State_Sponsored_Homophobia_2013.pdf |date=19 July 2013 }}</ref> In 2011, the Government informed the [[United Nations]] that it will not decriminalise homosexuality.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/jan/13/human-rights-watch-report-papua-new-guinea-australia-asylum-seekers Human Rights Watch says Papua New Guinea has failed to protect women and children], The Guardian, 12 January 2017</ref>
According to the [[United States Department of State]], there were no reports of prosecutions in 2012 directed at LGBT persons.<ref name="UNHCR 2012">[http://www.refworld.org/country,,,,PNG,,517e6df152,0.html "2012 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - Papua New Guinea"], United States Department of State</ref> However, the department reported that LGBT persons in 2012 were "vulnerable to societal stigmatization".<ref name="UNHCR 2012"/>
Former MP Dame [[Carol Kidu]] in 2012 described gay Papua New Guineans as being forced to live lives of secrecy, and called unsuccessfully on the Government to decriminalise homosexuality.<ref name="SBS b" /> Prime Minister [[Peter O'Neill]] explained that there were "strong feelings" against homosexuality in the country, which was "yet to accept such sexual openness".<ref name="SBS b">[http://www.sbs.com.au/news/video/2277690609/Gay-PNG-citizens-face-discrimination "Gay PNG citizens face discrimination"], Special Broadcasting Service (video), 11 September 2012</ref>
==Living conditions== LGBT persons have reported facing "discrimination in their daily lives, and often struggle to find jobs".<ref name="SBS 2012">[http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1691501/No-end-in-sight-to-PNGs-anti-gay-laws "No end in sight to PNG’s anti-gay laws"], [[Special Broadcasting Service]], 11 September 2012</ref>{{dead link|date=May 2018}}
There are a few nightclubs in [[Port Moresby]] that have "gay nights", mainly in [[Hanuabada]].<ref name="png"/>
==Summary table== {| class="wikitable" |- | Same-sex sexual activity legal | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] (For males)/[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] (For females) |- | Equal age of consent | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] (For males)/[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] (For females) |- | Anti-discrimination laws in employment only | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Anti-discrimination laws in the provision of goods and services | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Anti-discrimination laws in all other areas (Incl. indirect discrimination, hate speech) | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Same-sex marriages | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Recognition of same-sex couples | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Stepchild adoption by same-sex couples | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Joint adoption by same-sex couples | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | LGBT people allowed to serve openly in the military | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Right to change legal gender | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Access to IVF for lesbians | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | Commercial surrogacy for gay male couples | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |- | [[Men who have sex with men|MSM]]s allowed to donate blood | [[File:X mark.svg|15px|No]] |}
==See also== {{Portal|LGBT|Human rights}} *[[Human rights in Papua New Guinea]] *[[LGBT rights in Oceania]]
'''Tribes:''' *[[Etoro people]], a PNG tribe with traditional homosexual rituals *[[Sambia people]], a PNG tribe with traditional homosexual rituals *[[Kaluli people]], a PNG tribe with traditional homosexual rituals

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}} {{Language politics}} [[File:French and Flemish Sign in Brussels.jpg|thumb|The politics of language are evident in French-speaking Brussels, which is located in the Flanders region of Belgium, where people typically speak Flemish. Divisive preference of either language is avoided by using both French and Flemish on nearly all signs in Brussels.]] '''Language politics''' is the way language and linguistic differences between peoples are dealt with in the political arena. This could manifest as government recognition, as well as how language is treated in official capacities. Some examples:
*Legal status of a language as an [[official language]] in a [[jurisdiction (area)|country, state, or other jurisdiction]]. This generally means that all official documents affecting a country or region are published in the official language(s), but not in those that are not. Evidence in a court of law may also be expected to be presented in an official language.<ref name=Patten2011>{{cite journal |title= Political Theory and Language Policy |author= Alan Patten |journal= Political Theory |volume=29 |number=5 |date=October 2011 |pages=691–715 |publisher=Princeton|url= http://www.princeton.edu/~apatten/languagepolicy_politicaltheory.pdf |accessdate= September 7, 2018 |format=pdf|doi=10.1177/0090591701029005005}}</ref> *In countries where there are more than one main language, there are often political implications in decisions that are seen to promote one group of speakers over another, and this is often referred to as language politics. An example of a country with this type of language politics is [[Belgium]]. *In countries where there is one main language, immigrants seeking full [[citizenship]] may be expected to have a degree of fluency in that language ('language politics' then being a reference to the debate over the appropriateness of this). This has been a feature of [[Australian politics]]. *At various times [[minority language]]s have either been promoted or banned in schools, as politicians have either sought to promote a minority language with a view to strengthening the cultural identity of its speakers, or banning its use (either for teaching, or on occasion an entire ban on its use), with a view to promoting a national identity based on the majority language. An example of recent promotion of a minority language are [[Welsh language|Welsh]] or [[Leonese language|Leonese]] by the Leonese City Council, an example of official discouragement of a minority language is [[Breton language|Breton]]. *Language politics also sometimes relates to [[dialect]], where speakers of a particular dialect are perceived as speaking a more culturally 'advanced' or 'correct' form of the language. Politicians may therefore try to use that dialect rather than their own when in the public eye. Alternatively, at times those speaking the dialect perceived as more 'correct' may try to use another dialect when in the public eye to be seen as a 'man/woman of the people'. *To promote national identity, what are strictly dialects of the same language may be promoted as separate languages to promote a sense of national identity (examples include [[Danish language|Danish]] and [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] and [[Croatian language|Croatian]] – the latter two also use different scripts for what is linguistically the same language – [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] for Serbian and [[Latin alphabet|roman script]] for Croatian). Whether or not something is a language can also involve language politics, for instance, [[Political views on the Macedonian language|Macedonian]]. *The use of 'he' and other words implying the masculine in documents has been a political issue relating to [[women's rights]]. *The use of words which are considered by some to have negative implications to describe a group of people e.g. Gypsies (or even more negatively, 'Gypos') instead of [[Romani people|Romani]], or indeed using the term 'Gypsies' to cover [[Irish Traveller|Traveller]] peoples as well as Romanies. *'[[Political correctness]]' issues often stem from the use of words. For instance, some may object to the person in charge of an organisation being referred to as 'chairman', on the grounds that it implies a man must be in charge. *Co-existence of competing spelling systems for the same language, associated with different political camps. E.g. ** [[Debate on traditional and simplified Chinese characters]] ** [[Reforms of Russian orthography|Simplification of Russian orthography]]; proposals for such a reform were viewed as subversive in the late years of the Russian Empire and were implemented by the [[Bolshevik]]s in 1918, after which the "old orthography" became associated with the [[White movement]]. ** The two spelling systems for the [[Belarusian language]], one of which is associated with the country's political opposition. Language is also utilised in political matters to unify, organise and criticise in order to unify a political group. * The [[Moldovan Cyrillic alphabet]] preserved in [[Transnistria]].
